author: wassi

title: M8 Precision Rod holder - NEMA 17 stepper

description.text:
This is a short attempt at creating a 2-in-1 precision rod holder that can use the NEMA 17 stepper motor. There are two possible placements of the motor, one of them needing the bracket to be used.
In the linear actuator configuration, you simply use the bar holder on top of the NEMA 17, and then use your choice of clamp to secure a threaded rod to the motor shaft. 
In the belt configuration, you can use the provided bracket to attach the NEMA 17 to the back of the bar holder and run the belt through the hole.
Check the pictures for more detailed info. 
Also, check the attached SKP file if you need to change the model.

Printer:

Prusa i3 Graber

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes: Piece should be solid enough for most builds. Just to make sure it will hold, you can extrude the back of the bar holder even further (it's at 5mm thickness right now) to maybe 10mm.

author: emanuelbucsa

description.text:
Want a better way to level your print bed and get just the right nozzle height? Can you never seem to get the z endstop to stay in one place? Tired of changing start.gcode? Then this thing's for you! With kwixson's adjustable z endstop for prusa mendel, adjusting your nozzle height is as simple as turning a hex key.
This works with my x-end motor mount. Mileage may vary. Fully parametric. Season to taste. STL sized for metric M3 screws and nuts.

Put hex nut in nut well of the clip, fit over x-end motor mount and set with screw. Assemble plunger with spring, screw, three washers and three nuts.
Install and bring nozzle tip into light contact the print bed or plate at the home position. Adjust the end stop plunger to trip the endstop switch. Home the Z axis again to check adjustment. Home the Z axis in each corner of the print bed and adjust print bed height to light contact with the nozzle tip, matching the contact at Home X/Y. Adjust plunger to desired nozzle height (tighten it down by 1/8 or 1/16th turn).

comments.text: Nice! Do you need a resistor wired inline?
comments.author: totalitarian

comments.text:
If you using replicator on sailfish firmware:
When signal is HIGH - nothing happens.
When signal becomes LOW - stop function activates.
To do so you will need a pullup resistor (about 10k is ok). Connect it between signal input and +5v.
And to protect you SOC chip better to connect inline resistor (about 1k is ok). Connect inline to board signal input.

description.text:
I thought I saw a birthday candle lightsaber online, but I was wrong, so I decided to print one!  Turned out well for my wife's Star Wars themed birthday party.  (Amazing how much The Force Awakens party stuff Disney licenses already).
This design is intended to fit common birthday candles (at least in the US). Most of my candles fit well, shaving a hair of the wax off as I put them in.  A couple fit a little looser.  PLA may be looser.
It's a little taller than most candle holders, but it worked well and we all loved them!
WARNING: I have no clue if your printing material is food safe!!!!  Consider your materials and you're using them.  Think about discarding the part of the cake where the candle holder is.  I would recommend NOT licking the candle holders.
If you'd like to support my maker habits, please check out my Lego R2-D2's YouTube at http://youtube.com/myL3G0, and please tweet of facebook a link to his page, every visitor helps!

Printer:

FlashForge

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm (Standard)

Infill:

0%

Notes: Just printed them upside down, no rafts or supports. I used gray and they look nice without painting, some other colors would work as well. TIP: Print one and make sure your candle(s) fit before printing a dozen!
If you'd like to support my maker habits, please check out my Lego R2-D2's YouTube at http://youtube.com/myL3G0, and please tweet of facebook a link to his page, every visitor helps!

Cleaning up and optional painting Printing without supports worked well, but the button hangs out a bit from the edge so it drooped a little. I just filed that off. You can paint them if you want (again, WARNING: Check out whether you're using food-safe paint/materials). I was happy with the gray and didn't bother. Check out my 70% scale lightsaber for a typical painting pattern - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:724456 Check your candle sizes before you print a lot, I totally messed that up the first time. If you can find solid Star Wars color candles, that'd be cool Also a little longer than normal would have better proportions, though ours seemed to work OK. Oh, and most plastic filament burns, don't let the candles get down that far! Birthday Candles in Lightsaber Holders Example Paint Scheme (from 70% Lightsaber remixed source)

FWIW: Designing I remixed this from my 70% lightsaber - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:724456 - Check that out for examples of painting. Mostly I just shrunk the model and added a point under the tip. The hollow for the candle means that the narrow bits under the emitter need to be fatter, but it still is recognizable as a light saber. If you're looking for a bigger lightsaber check out the related things.

If you'd like to support my maker habits, please check out my Lego R2-D2's YouTube at http://youtube.com/myL3G0, and please tweet of facebook a link to his page, every visitor helps! Also what's that thing on http://BB-8.blogspot.com ???

I have a big floor fan that constantly tipped toward the ceiling because the adjustment nuts on it were loose. It came with knobs, so the nuts could be tightened by hand, but those knobs fell off and got lost. So now, new knobs! Hopefully I correctly understand what "parametric" means. The .scad file contains a single module call whose parameters can be adjusted to change the size and shape of the knob. If I misunderstood the point there, go easy on me, as this is my first Thing! Hope you like it! Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11326
Setting nut size - I set my knobs to 13 mm and they fit the 1/2" (12.7 mm) nuts very snugly (which is good!).  It probably depends on your nozzle width; mine is .4 mm, but YMMV.

comments.text: That is exactly what parametric means.  Parametric is good!

A "little" backpack for the FireFlo-frame when you are using a DIY vtx combination with a tx module.

My practice of reaction-diffusion model.
The reaction-diffusion system is a model to generate pattern of surface of some animals (such as zebra or fish). Nice explanation here: http://www.karlsims.com/rd.html .
Calculated pipe pattern with C program, place around coffee cup with OpenSCAD program.

Printer:

Da Vinci 2.0 duo

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes: If you would like to change reaction-diffusion pattern (various parameters of reaction-diffusion, random seed, resolution, # of iteration), edit "rdpipe.c", compile and run, redirect output to "rdpipe-sub.scad". The algorithm is Gray-Scott model on pipe world (top/bottom closed, left/right sides are continuous). To change design of the coffee cup, change "rdcup2.scad".
The outer reaction-diffusion skin does not fit to the coffee cup, so it's not actually a manifold object. I used Microsoft Model Repair service to fix it. Or solidify operation may work. The "rdpipe-sub.scad" is a part of OpenSCAD program, which initializes array v[] with the data. I don't have other skill/software to place matrix onto surface (or zmap), so did this way. Please comment better ways. I don't think supports are essential on some 3D printers.

I used C program to calculate reaction-diffusion system on matrix on pipe world, made output as OpenSCAD array v[] initializer sub program, then render with OpenSCAD.
The C source will be available soon. The another version (top photo left) has different diffusion parameters (i.e. patterns are thin), and kill rate the k differs between top and bottom.

This was inspired by Adamlamee's iPhone 5 Telescope mount. I had been using a re-mixed version of his until I upgraded to an iPhone 6. This was designed to fit a 32 mm eye piece. Printed with PLA It fit mine perfectly. If printing with ABS you may need to size it up slightly (something like 100.7%). The astro picture is Jupiter and four of it's moons. Not perfect, but far better than the morning before when I had to hold my phone to the eyepiece. I can't wait till our moon is full so I can capture some great pictures.

Printer:

Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: Nothing special with the print settings. If your bottom layer is too flat you might have to clean up the peg holes a little.

I printed this in two pieces so no support would be needed. I highly recommend using some superglue to hold the pieces together. I suspect the pegs could break off pretty easily otherwise. Just a little glue on the surface of the ring that touches the main body should suffice.
I also used a rubber band to hold my phone in. The fit probably doesn't require one, but better safe than sorry.

description.text:
60mm diameter dome housing for an FPV camera pan & tilt servos. The tilt servo sits within the housing to minimize aerodynamic drag. Recommended hardware for assembly is as follows:

  • Tilt servo: 23mm x 12mm servo. This design was based on a HK 933 servo (http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__14280__HobbyKing_8482_HK_933MG_Digital_MG_Servo_2_0kg_0_10sec_12g.html) The bottom of the mounting flange to the base of the output shaft should be about 10mm minimum.

  • Camera: Mini-CMOS type, with a body of 11.5mm x 11.5 mm. This design was based on the following: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__64499__Mini_CMOS_FPV_Camera_520TVL_90deg_Field_Of_Vision_0_008LUX_11_5_x_11_5_x_21mm_NTSC_.html

  • M2x8 bolts & nuts (2x) - for servo mounts

  • No. 2 screws (2x) - for attaching servo mounts into the dome

  • M3x10 bolt and nut (1x) - for mounting the bracket to the right side of the dome

  • 3x6x2.5mm flanged bearing - for the right side of the bracket

  • 8mm length screw/bolt & washer - for the left side of the bracket/servo horn
    • You may have to use different hardware, depending on your equipment.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

I have included pictures of the components in various stages of assembly - I hope these are self-explanatory. Some hints/notes:

  • There is a beveled hex-shaped cutout in the inside top of the dome right side. This is intended to hold an M3 nut to allow a M3 bolt to be screwed in from the outside. The cutout will not be visible after printing due to the bridge layer. You will have to slightly crush the edges of the bridge layer enough to allow the M3 nut to seat partially - once you do this you can use a temporary M3 bolt screwed in from the outside, tightening it down such that the nut gets compressed into the cutout. When you remove the temporary bolt you will be left with a wedged-in nut ready for the actual bolt. The pic of the inside of the dome right-side shows what the end result should look like.

  • The camera is simply held in by friction. You may want to put a dab of hot glue or other semi-permanent adhesive to prevent it from getting pushed into the housing.

  • The "left" and "right" side of the dome are arbitrary names - that is, you can have the left be the right side, depending on which side you want the wires to come out, or if you want to have the pan servo above the housing, etc.

  • There is a cutout in the bracket on the servo side which is intended to hold the servo arm but you will still have to secure the bolt end. You will probably not be able to use the stock servo horn screw/bolt for this, due to the thickness of the bracket. The HK 933 servo can accept an M2 bolt so I simply used an M2x8 bolt & washer. YMMV. You may be able to get by with glueing the horn to the bracket.

  • Any 23mm x 12mm servo should be able to serve as the tilt servo - however, the critical dimension is the flange-to-output shaft height. It must be great enough (about 10mm minimum) to allow the shaft to protrude through the dome hole enough to be able to fit the servo horn. I unsuccessfuly tried using a Hitec HS-5055MG servo - but its shaft does not reach the dome wall.

  • You do not have to glue the dome halves together. The 2 pins plus the bracket tension should be enough to hold it together. I recommend against gluing them as that will make it more difficult to separate for servicing.

Effector (head assembly) for E3D V6 head on a mini Kossel, or any delta printer where the standard mini Kossel head is used.
I couldn't find an effector that suited my needs so i designed one of my own.
I'm currently using this effector on my mini Kossel and it works great. But if you find any issues or have suggestions for improvements just let me know. Also let me know if there is information missing that you think should be in this text.
I will update this thingi soon with assembly manual and pictures. The Probe part is designed for a 2mm allen key and should be about 77mm long for the mechanical switch and also for the manually operated optical switch. For the Optical Z-probe with magnet retraction the allen key needs to be 80-85mm long.
Use the part cooler with probe support for this one.
Thankyou Marco Robustini for suggesting this part and for your assistance during developing.
http://www.thingiverse.com/Marco67/about
Marcos video showing how it works: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bCDQ0ObWXnk&t=7s
And here is the BLTouch: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MPdJW-fVP-E Probe offset is Y=-7,5mm X=-13. Probe should be orientated towards X tower.
Also note the orientation of the E3D V6 head in the picture. Printed parts in ABS and PETG. Tried 0.2mm and 0.1mm layer thickness and both work well with a 0.4mm nozzle.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

RepRap Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25

Notes: Printed my with 0.4 nozzle.

comments.text:
I think the original Kossel design has the option to extract the probe by sweeping it by the GT2 belt and retraction is made by pressing the probe up against a screw beside the heatbed.
My design does not have the spring needed at the top that automatically flips the probe to "parked" position when it's pressed up. So to use the probe you need to release or park it by hand.

comments.text:
Šis stāsts man vienmēr ir licies tik ļoti patiess un īpašs. Tas pierāda, ka mūsu dzīvēs viss ir iespējams. Jā, pat kaķis VAR iemācīt kaijai lidot.
Bet vienmēr ir viens bet.
Viss ir atkarīgs no mūsu gribēšanas un mūsu darīšanas. Iedomājieties, cik jauki būtu, ja šāds kaķis dzīvotu ikvienā no mums? Bet patiesībā jau viņš ir mūsos, vienkārši ne katrs to ir atradis jeb atkal atcerējies. Ikvienā no mums ir arī kaija, kura nepārtraukti šaubās un negrib ticēt sev. Ikvienā no mums ir kaķis, kurš tic, ka tu to vari un ka tu to izdarīsi. Un līdzko jūs salaidīsiet savu kaiju un savu kaķi kopā, tā viss notiksies, viss ritināsies uz priekšu.
comments.author: Sanbela

author: nishangrandhi

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0YbV4BgXznA

This is an oval shaped little vase meant for racing, ie the better your machine's cooling system the faster you can get around the oval. My stock Ultimaker can run this at 40 mm/s without defects.  
Defects show up on the side away from the fan at 50 mm/s and on the side towards the fan at 70 mm/s.   
It will be interesting to see what cooling system mods work best to get higher speeds.

Cura Settings for PLA racing on the Ultimaker: under tools: switch to full settings under the basic tab:
Layer height: 0.2 mm
Shell thickness: 0.4 mm
Bottom thickness: 0.4 mm
Print speed: 40 mm/s to qualify and then as fast as you can
Printing temp: 210 C under the advanced tab:
minimal layer time: SET to 0 seconds under expert settings:
uncheck solid infill top
check solid infill bottom

comments.text: This is absolutely brilliant.
comments.author: Neutrons1313

comments.text:
You should turn on "Spiralize the outer contour" in Expert config in Cura for better print! ;)
Also I printed vase at 100 mm\s with this cooling system http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15316 , and result was as yours 60 mm\s. :)

While drilling the VINDRUVA the acrylic (that is very thin) started to crack, so I decided to do some decorative frames to hide the disgrace. Because I have a helloBEEprusa, I used an honeycomb theme.
I suggest you to use a soldering iron to make the holes by melting the acrylic, that's how I concluded the job.

Melt multiple colors of ABS plastic in Acetone and keep it in an airtight container that will not melt from the Acetone.  
After printing the wings, lay them down on a piece of glass or plastic that acetone does not affect.  Fill in the wings in a symetrical pattern with the various colors.  
Create a cotter pin with a paper clip and fit them all together with the little hinge parts and the cotter pin.

author: cdeschrun

title: Normal Size 6 Sided Die or Dice

description.text:
My daughter just learned about Farkle and we were missing one die. She's used to playing with 6 dice and we only had 5. She asked if I could print one, and as any DIY father would say, "Absolutely!" Well the problem was that I couldn't find any normal size die on Thingiverse so I decided to quickly design what I consider to be a "standard" size die.  
I measured an existing die using my calipers and it was about 16mmx16mmx16mm. Those are the dimensions I used to design in Rhino 3D. I'm still learning 3D design and Rhino, but I did print this design and it worked quite nicely.

comments.text: One of the best things I made, but is weighted.

description.text: This object features Open in Customizer So you have DMM, Oscope and other equipment probes or cables, but they seem to "walk away"? Why not corral them with this parametric probe holder! This thing has been used for drafting pens, white board markers and trimming tools. But that's not all; this holder can hold any cylindrical thing. It can easily manage test cables, tools, syringes, and even test tubes (by changing the clasp arc to a closed ring). Just download, or better yet open in customizer, and edit. Simply enter in number of probes, the shaft diameter and guard dimensions. You can leave the rest at the defaults if you really want to get in and get making. You can optionally change the mount hole diameter, fastener (screw or bolt) type, and if you want a countersunk mount. Even add a center tab on a long holder. You can also edit some advanced options for even finer control over the holder, but it's strictly not necessary. Lastly you can make a tailored or bespoke holder to collect different kinds of probes in one holder. We show you how by editing the OpenSCAD file as outlined in instructions below.

Printer:

Felix 3.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20 to 0.25 mm

Infill:

20 to 40%

Notes: Print at higher resolutions for a better looking part. But let's be honest, this is probe holder - nobody is going to care what it looks like. It just has to work; use the lowest resolution that still gives you a sturdy part. At typical probe sizes only solid fill is created by slicers, so the percentage won't matter. Suggest you print this thing on its side (rotate x-axis 90 degrees) with supports, so the mount holes and tabs print cleanly.

Step 1: Find build_vector So if you want to make a tailored or bespoke holder, you will need to download and edit the .scad file for this object. You will find a vector (OpenSCAD for Array) commented out in the file (see lines 76 to 81 in the screenshot below). Locate all the lines for declaration of build_vector to the very end of the declaration. This includes the line that contains ]; by itself. Commented out build_vector Step 2: Activate build_vector Now simply remove the double slash // at the beginning of each of these lines (like the screenshot below). Activated build_vector Step 3: Edit build_vector Now edit the vector for your probes. For example you have two pair of probes:
  • 2 DMM Probes: 8.4 mm in diameter with a circular guard 12.5 mm in diameter
  • 2 Oscope Probes: 11.2 mm in diameter with a circular guard 14.6 mm in diameter
    • The edited vector would look like the screenshot below. Example build_vector Step 4: Generate Now generate the GCAL and export the STL. If this is your first time using OpenSCAD; it's easy! Just hit the GCAL generate button (highlighted in red) and then the STL export button (highlighted in green) from the edit window (shown below). Button locations

Customizer Parameters Edit the parameters to make the probe holder as needed. In Customizer the OpenSCAD code generates a holder that will hold many probes of the same type. The customizer and variables in the source are divided into only general, mount tabs and advanced sections:

  • General

    • Count
      Number of probes for this holder
    • Probe Diameter (mm)
      Diameter of the probe shaft or handle
    • Guard Width (mm)
      Diameter of guard along the width
    • Guard Depth (mm)
      Diameter of the guard perpendicular to the mounting plate

  • Mount Tabs

    • Center Tab (auto/ yes/ no)
      Add center tab (yes = add tab, auto = automatically add tab on 'long' flexible holder)
    • Mount Hole (yes/ no)
      Make holes in mounting tabs (yes = make holes)
    • Mount Hole Diameter (mm)
      Width of screw used to mount holder to cabinet or wall
    • Fastener Type
      Type of bolt or screw head
    • Countersink (yes/ no)
      Countersink the mounting hole (yes = countersink)

  • Advanced
    Normally just go with the defaults but alter at your own risk. Changes here may make unprintable parts.

    • Holder Height (mm)
    • Mount Thickness (mm)
    • Clasp Arc (degrees)
      Set arc width for the maw of the probe clasp (360 = closed ring)
    • Clasp Thickness (mm)
      Wall thickness of the clasp
    • Clasp Clearance (mm)
      Space between neighboring clasps
    • Resolution
      Line segments used to make a circle. Note the higher the number the longer the render will grind making your part. At "Insane" it may take longer than 30 minutes before customizer coughs up your part.
    • Oversize (mm)
      How much larger to make the clasp diameter for a good fit
    • Revison History This is the fifteenth revision (v0.8.13) that has implemented the following fixes since the original:
  • Migration from previous project
  • Added guard depth and build vector
  • Beta code release
  • Added oversize for better clasp fit
  • Changed to clearance rather than proportional object modeling
  • Removed edge filleting
  • Fixed clasp attachment calculation and clarified wording
  • Fixed right tab placement (thanks to furicks)
  • Smallest probe diameter improved to 4mm
  • Smallest probe diameter further improved to less than 1mm
  • Tweaked clasp attachment to work better with smaller probe diameters
  • Fixed clasp build modules for cleaner clasps
  • Added option to create without holes in mounting tabs (thanks to RobinSwa)
  • Modified guard width and depth limits to up 20mm guards in Customizer
  • Add center tab and altered customizer oversize parameter to 1/10 of mm
  • Set center tab to autogenerate on long probe holder and set oversize default to .1 mm
  • Fixed right tab placement gap between probe body and tab
  • Fixed oversize adjustment calculation
    • Seems the design is (mostly) stable but evolving.

Ok, I'm all for house parties, especially when there's a saucy, sexy, redhead engineer babe that tells you she wants to see your "makerbot" in action... This, my maker-friends, is when you need to take a millisecond (or 60000) to ponder what might go wrong. Will she be impressed by your feed rate, or will she marvel at your layer thickness? Or, will she be impressed by both and, with a single stroke of her dominant hand, clear the desk of your (pro) soldering iron, calibration cubes, hex wrenches, your Bamboo Fun (pen) tablet, and FULL GLASS OF RED WINE, only to satisfy her technically-motivated libido? Take a moment (1000 ms max). She's hot. She's also left-handed, which means if your MakerBot is located to the left of your workspace's epicenter, your makerbot just might get lucky. Let's consider the trifecta of the maker-male's inner drive: #1 Downstairs. #2. Upstairs. #3 Your 3D printer (these are in no particular order) With a quick flip of a switch and a tug (lol) of two (arguably three) cables, your 3D printer is saved. That takes care of #3. As long as you're cognizant of #3's future, #2 doesn't care (its tipsy enough anyway since you decided to put your FULL GLASS OF RED WINE right next to your 3d printer..), which leaves #1. Good ol' #1. He's fine. No comment. This is your fair warning, maker-community! Sincerely,
Jinx

title: PARIS lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I live in Paris and I love this city. Yes, it's beautiful, filled with impressive architecture, history and culture, but what I enjoy the most in Paris is the enthusiasm most citizen share for good food, music and "happy hours" in their favorite cafe. What happened last Friday, only a few meters from the bar I chose to celebrate the weekend with my friends, can't be described. My way to fight these barbarian is to keep celebrating what they hate. History, liberty, art and love of beauty on earth.
This Lamp inspired by Gustave Eiffel's most famous construction is a reminder that the city of light will always be the symbol of all these things, no matter what they do to it.
-Samuel N. Bernier

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Notes: This big lamp is designed to be printed in multiple parts, each fitting the build volume of a REPLICATOR 2. Or in a single shot on a Z18 The parts are designed to be printed WITHOUT support.

Assembly Remove the Raft and clip the parts together. They slide and snap to one another. Use a threaded E27 light socket with an LED light bulb.
You might use epoxy glue to secure the assembly if needed.

title: Simple Flame Wheel Landing gear for battery/camera tray+gimbal

description.text: Landing gear to screw onto the body of the Flame wheel by DJI. The general idea is to have enough space for a battery tray as well as a gimbal. hope you like it :D

Printer:

CoLiDo 2.0 3D Printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2-0.3

Infill:

100% for best strength, min 25% honeycomb

Notes: Use 3mm (M3) bolts to fasten it down to the frame. should print without problem on makerbot replicator sized printers (15x14x14.5).

just rip off the supports and sand down the bottom so it looks nice. re-drill the holes as they probably wont be perfect, I made them a little smaller so you can either chose to thread the bolt through without drilling to get a snug fit, or drill them out to get a smooth fit(of course you should use nuts as well, I don't think the smaller hole will be strong enough to hold it :P)

with no other landing gears that resemble this one, i set out to make my own :D
I first outlined dji's official landing gear's profile and built it up in 3D software, then I added the plate on top and put holes in it that matched the Flamewheel quadcopter frame. ive tried them on my home made tricopter(I used the flamewheel plates as a battery tray and bolted them on to that) and they work beautifully

I have a bit of a collection of mechanical keyboards, each with a different type of switch. I got tired of having some in my closet and others taking up desk space so I came up with this solution. These brackets are designed to be adhered to the wall with some strong double sided tape so there are no screws to be seen when a keyboard is off its shelf. 
The small size I designed for ten-key-less (TKL) keyboards, has an arm length of 160cm. The medium size I designed for average full size keyboards, the arm length is 175cm. I may eventually draw a larger size if necessary but I think if they're any longer it will become too unstable without modifying the back of the bracket. 
Version 1.0 has filleted edges which look nice in the model but unfortunately didn't print very well on my printer. Version 1.1 removes the fillets and also reduces the thickness of the part as I determined it wasn't necessary to be so thick.
I uploaded the SolidWorks part files for each version as well so anyone can make further modifications.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: I printed the ones shown with ABS, when I tried version 1.0 without raft the fillets on the bottom turned out poorly because the corners lifted up so I printed version 1.1 with rafts. I was able to print a pair of brackets at the same time on my Replicator Dual by rotating them a few times on the build plate in MakerBot Desktop. It may be more difficult to print two at the same time if you have a smaller build plate. Each pair took about 3 hours to print using MakerBot's new diamond infill set at 10%.

Finishing As soon as the print was done I peeled the raft off because I found it easiest to remove when the print is still hot. (Be careful not to burn your fingers!) Once the part cooled I dampened a rag with acetone and wiped the part down to make the raft side look cleaner. I cut a strip of 3M 411-MEDIUM Medium Outdoor Mounting Tape the length of the back part of the bracket and cut it in half, one half for each bracket. Based on my smallest keyboard, I measured and marked the location of the brackets on the wall so they would all be uniform. (Mine are about 18 cm apart) Because the arms are at 45 degree angles I was able to put the brackets up against each other to maximize the space. In my setup I put one medium bracket on the bottom and three small brackets on top of it.

title: "Igloo Of Penguins" Tux the Penguin Game Piece

description.text:
A game piece for an open source version of "Barrel of Monkeys." modeled after Tux, the Linux mascot and open source celebrity. Still a work in progress, and as I don't have my Prusa assembled yet, I have no idea if it's even printable yet. Changelog:
9/15/11 - Merged all parts into single mesh.

comments.text: Just thought I would give you some feed back since you are new. Yes it will print, but skeinforge will do some strange things because its made of multiple intersecting parts. Ideally you want the model to be one continuous mesh with no extra faces inside the model. When slicing this skeinforge may see some the the intersecting parts as hollows as well as create walls inside the model in the shape of each the parts that make up the model. You can Boolean them together using a union in your modelling software. Or possibly download mesh mixer and use it to join the individual parts (in wine). :)
comments.author: SayNoToMakerbot

comments.text: Thanks for the tip. I thought that it might cause some problems not being a single mesh. I could have sworn I fixed that, though. I'll give your program a try. The other programs I'm using are causing some issues. I need to try and ween myself off of anim8or and use something a bit more powerful and up to date.
comments.author: SayNoToMakerbot

comments.text: I use Blender 2.5x and have to say it is amazingly powerful. It can boolean together broken meshes which no other program I have seen can do. It does have a learning curve unlike no other modelling program out there because they strayed from the conventional interface found in most cad program ever since autocad. But its free, open source and can do anything.

This is a remix of the excellent design of Ralf's Perstaltic pump. I printed his pump and built it to his specs, but I found that the small stepper motors would not really run the pump consistently or with enough power.
I decided to modify the pump to accept a Nema 17 stepper. This gives the pump PLENTY of power to push whatever liquid that you're trying to push. I had to beef up the bearing holders a bit. I also added some mounts. There's a single pump mount and a 4 pump mount. (I'm using to add fertilizers to my aquarium, so I use the 4 pump version).
I'm still using the same bearings and screws that Ralf is using, so you can get a list of the required screws and bearings from his thing. There are countersunk holes in the pump base to mount the motor. If you don't use the motor mount, I've included a spacer to use in it's place.
The washer goes in-between the bearing and the bearing holder assembly on both sides. You can also use metal washers, but I found you can adjust the printed ones for a perfect fit.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Variable

Infill:

Variable

Notes: For the bearing mounts, use an infill of at least 50% - You need the strength. I also used 60% infill for the pump top, base and centre - This ensures that everything will handle the stress. The mounting plate and base you can use as little as you can get away with, but better infill means more strength. The pump housing was printed with 4 shells. The bearing holders and mounting plates with 2 shells. I printed everything at 100 microns, but I think that 200 microns should be ok for everything but the small parts.
You probably won't need support -I was able to print everything without. (I always TRY to design to print without support.

Building the pump I used a 12V 350mA 28oz-in NEMA 17 stepper motor from Robotshop. Part number RB-Ada-138. This motor has a shaft with a flattened side. I recommend this to keep the bearing mount from slipping.
For the screws and bearings needed, see thing 254956.
You will also need screws for the motor.
I created this from the original files found on thing 254956.  I brought them into Sketchup and modified them to work with a NEMA 17 stepper.

comments.text:
It is already designed for 1/4" (6.4mm) hose. Make sure that you are using the very flexible silicone type hose. The normal vinyl (e.g. Aquarium airline) hose is too rigid.
It should be able to handle that flow quite fine, as long as you print in ABS or a good curable resin. PLA, I find, will crack under stress long before ABS will.
Also, if you have difficulty with the hose size, try a different sized bearing. Just make sure the height and inner hole of the bearing are the same size.

comments.author: alexvez

comments.text:
Hi Alex,
I use an A4988 for each stepper. The Pololu board, see the link http://www.canadarobotix.com/stepper-motor-controllers/pololu-1182
I'm using the same M3 screws. They were actually a pain to find locally. I'm in Canada, which is Metric, but good luck finding metric screws! I was going to change the design to imperial screws, but since I had found the screws and they were sitting there, I decided to leave them.
There's not much laxity, but I am using my printed washer, because I can sand it down a bit for a perfect fit.
I am using 6 bearings. I didn't change much on the bearing holder other than to change the hole to support the Nema steppers and to increase the strength of he area around the mount to support the torque of the larger motor.
I don't think it would be too hard to convert to a single bearing. I would use a slightly wider bearing though. In Canada I order from Www.bearingscanada.com.
One note... With the current design, I find it very predictable to dispense the liquid down to about .2ml. I run the stepper at 1/4 step and count the clicks. There's a fair bit of pressure on the hose, so the amount of vertical head does not seem to affect the performance or accuracy. with this design I found that I also did not need check valves to prevent backflow. The pressure on the hose was enough to seal the line.

My kids love the octopus, and kept asking for a starfish. This did the trick! I drew this in sketchup freehand. It took quite some time to get the surface right. Looks very topographic once printed. A great flat bottomed animal for the Makerbot. Perhaps a flounder is next up :)
Update: This prints really well if you scale it up as well, I've printed it so that it just fits on the build platform, takes a bit longer, but comes out great. Sort of neat that the ends of the feet tend to curl up a little due to the heating/cooling of the plastic.
Was very odd but overnight these things crawled up on a few rocks I'd left on the table...
Update 10/15/2011: if your original needs a companion, check out Squiggly version.

I print these using raftless printing configured basically how they describe on the makerbot wiki (http://wiki.makerbot.com/thingomatic-doc:raftless). The modifications I made are: 1) I changed the Object First Layer Feed Rate Infill Multiplier (ratio) to be 0.5 2) I change the Object First Layer Feed Rate Permieter Multiplier (ratio) to 0.5 3) I changed the Object First Layer Flow Rate Multiplier (ratio) to 0.9 4) I disabled the Outline feature and generally delete the lines of gCode that do the warm up extrusion.
These changes make the first layer go down slower and a little wider/thicker so that it adheres to the platform very well. I was noticing that the outline and warm-up extrusion generally left buggers or lines of plastic that then caused the early layers to peal off. The changes above fixed that.

comments.text: I got a question on email about drawing these, so figured I just share here...  So to draw this in Sketchup, I draw the flat surface first, then I draw lines straight up off that surface in various places to the height I think I want.  I then use these as reference points for the tops of arcs that I draw (start/end of arc is on the flat bottom surface).  I set the segments for the arcs at like 12 or 24.  After a bunch of arcs are in place I then draw a ton of triangles to connect the arcs together and form a closed surface between them.

comments.text: Can anyone share with me the secret to printing differences colors at different layers? How do you go about switching out colors during the build without messing everything up? Thanks!
comments.author: kevinkline4124

comments.text: Best way I've found is to clip the filament with some nail cutters close (just above) to where it feeds into the extruder and then follow this cut end in by pushing the next color in on top of it as it feeds into the extruder.  Takes a minute or 2 for it to start extruding but is the best for not messing up the build.  Other option that works OK is to click Pause (preferable while it is in the in-fill stage and not doing the outline if you can time it right, there is a little pause) in ReplicatorG, pull out the current filament and stick in the new one.  This makes the color start to come out a lot faster, but does cause more risk of bubbles, air pockets, etc...  Good luck!
comments.author: kevinkline4124

comments.text: Thanks! I will have to try it sometime. Using the pause method was the way I was thinking you could do it but I like the idea of simply feeding it in by hand after cutting the first one a little better.

title: Prusa i3 rev1.5 improved extruder (E3D v6 compatible)

description.text:
This is a modified version of the extruder of the Prusa i3 rev 1.5 from eMotion Tech , with 2 modifications:
  • I increased the length of the capacitive probe holder to enable the use of longer hot ends than the suggested hexagon, such as the E3Dv6 and the Pico
  • I increased the thickness of the part connecting to the X carriage to increase rigidity
    • 01/30/2016: added the 123dx file

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30%

Notes: Printed both in PLA and xt-CF20 (for increased rigidity)

Flone it's an airframe for flying smartphones. Video of maiden flight:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pBsdF9hWk-o This is the old version 1.0 of the airframe. New version is available on:
http://flone.cc App for control:
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=processing.test.floneremote It has the place for a minimal setup:
  • Android smartphone.
  • Multiwii controller.
  • Mini Power Distribution Board.
  • Controlled by Bluetooth / DSM2.
  • 4 motors
  • 4 ESC
  • Batery.
    • We enjoy designing it, it's well balanced and has the space for a clear field of view of the camera. The design includes a tiny Flone PDB integrating airframe and XT60 power connector. Enjoy-it! Get updated with new improvements in the airframe and the Android App in the webpage of the project:
    http://flone.cc PROJECT PRODUCED UNDER THE CALL NEXT THINGS 2013: NEXT SPACE.
    Organized by:
    Telefonica I+D
    LABoral centro de Arte y Creacion Industrial

Parts needed:
  • 4 x motors
  • 4 x ESC
  • Battery
  • Flight Controller
  • DSM2 Radio Receiver.
    • For cut the frame we choose a 5mm plywood, it's cheap and absorb the impacts pretty well.
  • Buy materials.
  • Cut the frame with a laser cutter, or print it in a paper, glue it and cut manually.
  • Assembly it (main frame + horizontal arms + legs) and glue it.
  • Attach flight controller to electronic plate..
    4 Attach DSM2 /Bluetooth to electronic plate.
  • Solder Flone PDB
  • Configure Flight controller
  • Check the motor directions and solder them.
  • Put propellers.
  • Fly with your smartphone.
    • It's important to have some safety in mind working with this robots, put propellers in the last step of the construction to avoid accidents. We love electric zips, to attach eveything: are light, cheap and it's the first thing to broke before an arm, an axis of the motor or a propeller. Enjoy!

remixed_from.author: dwalton

title: "Towel" Plane Parts, Servo/Motor Mounts & Drop Mechanism

description.text:
This is a set of parts to use when building the MAKE Magazine "Towel" RC plane, by Breck Baldwin.
There are two servo mounts for the elevons, control arms for the elevons, a motor mount, a taller servo mount for a drop mechanism and a couple guide parts for the drop mechanism.
There are also two hooks that can be printed out to hang your plane and radio transmitter to keep the plane out of harms way.
I have added the solidworks files for all of the parts of the plane.

1 - Read the article from MAKE - http://makezine.com/projects/make-30/the-towel-rc-stunt-plane/
2 - Download & Print out all of the parts
3 - Find a small screw (I use a #2-56 x 1/2" long screw) that will fit into the counter-bored hole in the motor mount to clamp the motor. Adjust the motor mount bore to suit your motor mounting diameter. I used a tapered reamer to get the fit just right before clamping with the screw.
4 - Assemble the plane using the printed parts - the slots in the parts are for using tie wraps to secure the parts to the deck. Refer to the attached picture for component placement.
5 - The drop mechanism is something I developed as an addition. I have it plugged into the 5th channel on my radio, normally used for landing gear, so the switch on my remote makes dropping the payload easy. The rubber bands are attached at the edges of the wings, with a taped on reinforcement (I used a short piece of wire with the ends bent into circles). Make a hole through the wing that is the same size of the hole in the drop mechanism guide. The free end of the rubber band has a small metal loop that goes up through a hole in the plane wing, and is what accepts the end of the drop rod. See the video in the download section to see it in action.
6 - Practice dropping the payloads. I like to use soft foam rockets or little parachute men, as they are light and soft. If it does not release fully, open up the diameter of the hole through the wing. Also, note the position of the foam rocket in the picture - I positioned it so the free end of the rubber band is perpendicular to the bottom of the wing surface. It is less likely to get stuck if it is positioned this way.
7 - Bombs Away!!
8 - Print out the hooks, mount to the wall, and hang your plane out of the way and show it off!
